properties.title: Birthplace of Peking Opera
properties.description: Beijing became the endpoint for Huiban troupes, with the Sanqing Troupe’s 1790 arrival marking a turning point. Their blend of styles led to Peking Opera, known for its 'Huguang Yun' tone.

properties.title: Elegant Style of Zaju
properties.description: Zaju in Luoyang adopted poetic elegance, contrasting with Bianjing’s livelier style through its literary grace and refined expression.

properties.title: Birthplace of Zaju Opera
properties.description: Kaifeng, the birthplace of Zaju opera, saw performances flourish in washa and goulan districts during the Song Dynasty. Its role system—Dan, Mo, Jing, and Za—became a lasting tradition.

properties.title: Home of Nan Opera
properties.description: In the Yuan Dynasty, Zaju moved south to Hangzhou, where it merged with Wenzhou’s Nanxi drama, creating a lyrical style that shaped Southern opera traditions.

properties.title: Cradle of Nan Opera
properties.description: Yongjia region in Wenzhou birthed Nanxi during the Southern Song. As northern Zaju moved south, it blended with local forms, replacing fixed acts with long-form storytelling that shaped Southern opera.

properties.title: Literary Roots and the Rise of Kunqu
properties.description: In the Yuan Dynasty, playwrights like Guan Hanqing brought literary refinement to Zaju in Jiangnan. In Suzhou, it merged with Pingtan storytelling, laying the groundwork for Kunqu Opera.

properties.title: Gateway to the Capital
properties.description: Yangzhou, a key stop for Huiban troupes heading to Beijing, played a role in the rise of Peking Opera. It is also the birthplace of Yangju Opera and once a center for Kunqu, enriching its operatic heritage.

properties.title: Canal Theater and the Birth of Huaihong Opera
properties.description: At Qingjiangpu in Huai’an, grass-stage troupes performed along the canal. Northern Bangzi troupes merged with local Huaihai Opera, creating Huaihong Opera—known for its Mandarin-style spoken lines.
